content.text: The value \(l_0\) is the length of the spring when the load \(L\) is 0.0N
Measure the unstretched length \(l_0\) of the spring. Do **not** include the loops at the ends of the spring in your measurement
Record \(l_0\) in cm to the nearest mm in Table 1.1
Draw a diagram of the spring to show clearly the length \(l_0\) of the spring
The metre ruler is clamped in position near to the spring. Do **not** change the position of the metre ruler
Suspend a load \(L = 1.0 \text{N}\) from the spring
Record the new length \(l\) of the spring in Table 1.1
Calculate the extension \(e\) of the spring using the equation \(e = (l - l_0)\)
Record the value of \(e\) in Table 1.1
Repeat the procedure using loads \(L = 2.0 \text{N}, 3.0 \text{N}, 4.0 \text{N}\) and 5.0N
Plot a graph of \(L / N\) ( \(y\)-axis) against \(e / \text{cm}\) ( \(x\)-axis)
Draw the best-fit line
Use the graph to determine \(e_{\mathrm{A}}\), the extension produced by a load of 2.5N. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
In this experiment, you will investigate the stretching of a spring
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1
Use the thermometer to measure the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\)
Pour \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker. Place the lid on the beaker. Place the thermometer in the hot water in the beaker
Record, in Table 2.1, the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water at time \(t = 0\). Immediately start the stop-watch
Continue recording the temperature in Table 2.1 at 30 s intervals until you have seven sets of readings
Complete the column headings in Table 2.1
Calculate the decrease in temperature \(\Delta \theta\) between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
\(\Delta \theta =\)
Calculate the average rate of cooling \(R\) of the water using the equation \(R = \frac{\Delta \theta}{\Delta t}\),
where \(\Delta t = 180 \text{s}\). Include the unit
R =
A student states that the water cools slowly

Suggest two changes to the experiment that you could make to increase the rate of cooling of the hot water without changing the starting temperature of the hot water. Room temperature remains constant
State one precaution that you take to obtain accurate temperature readings
Explain briefly the reason for this precaution
statement
explanation
In this experiment, you will investigate the cooling of water
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1
Draw a line across the ray-trace sheet supplied, approximately in the middle. Label the line \(\mathbf{PQ}\)
· Place the transparent block, largest face down, with the straight side on the line \(\mathbf{PQ}\) and the curved side below the line
· Draw round the outline of the block. Label the ends of the straight side of the block \(\mathbf{A}\) and \(\mathbf{B}\)
· Remove the block and draw the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\) through the centre of \(\mathbf{AB}\). Continue the normal so that it passes through the curved side of the block
· Label the point \(\mathbf{C}\) where the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\) crosses \(\mathbf{AB}\)
Draw the line \(\mathbf{DC}\) at an angle \(i = 20^{\circ}\) to the normal, as shown in Fig. 3.1
Place the paper on the pin board
* Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), on line \(\mathbf{DC}\) at a suitable distance apart for this experiment

* Replace the block and look from the position of the eye shown in Fig. 3.1 to observe the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through side \(\mathbf{AB}\) of the block. Adjust your line of sight until the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear one behind the other

* Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), between your eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_3\), \(\mathsf{P}_4\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other
* Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_1\), \(\mathsf{P}_2\), \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\)
* Remove the block and the pins
* Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Continue the line to \(\mathbf{AB}\)
* Label \(\mathbf{E}\), the end of the line furthest from \(\mathbf{AB}\)
Measure the acute angle \(\theta\) between the line \(\mathbf{NL}\) and the line \(\mathbf{EC}\). (An acute angle is less than \(90^{\circ}\).)
State one precaution that you take to produce an accurate ray trace
• On the ray-trace sheet, draw a line \(\mathbf{FC}\) at an angle \(i = 70^{\circ}\) to the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\), as shown in Fig. 3.2
• Replace the transparent block on the ray-trace sheet in the position shown in Fig. 3.2
• Place pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line \(\mathbf{FC}\) at a suitable distance apart for this type of experiment
Observe the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through the curved side of the block. Look from the position of the eye shown in Fig. 3.2
• Adjust your line of sight until the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear one behind the other

• Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\), between your eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_5\), \(\mathsf{P}_6\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other
• Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\)
• Remove the block and the pins
• Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\). Continue the line to \(\mathbf{AB}\)
• Label \(\mathbf{G}\), the end of the line furthest from \(\mathbf{AB}\)
Measure the acute angle \(\theta\) between the line \(\mathbf{NL}\) and the line \(\mathbf{GC}\). (An acute angle is less than \(90^{\circ}\).)
Tie your ray-trace sheet into this question booklet between pages 8 and 9
In this experiment, you will investigate the refraction of light using a semicircular transparent block
Carry out the following instructions, using the separate ray-trace sheet provided. You may refer to Fig. 3.1 and Fig. 3.2 for guidance
Fig. 3.1
A student investigates the change in current in a conducting liquid as the distance between two electrodes is changed. The circuit is shown in Fig. 4.1
Plan an experiment to investigate the change in current in the liquid as the distance between the electrodes is changed
You are **not** required to do this investigation
You should:

explain briefly how to do the investigation
state the key variables to keep constant
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display your readings (you are
not required to enter any readings in the table)
explain how to use your readings to reach a conclusion.
• explain briefly how to do the investigation
state the key variables to keep constant
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
explain how to use your readings to reach a conclusion
